about.title: About :-
about.description:
I'm Lunex, a dedicated backend developer with a strong foundation in system design and performance optimization. My expertise lies in building robust server-side applications and RESTful APIs. I'm also an active competitive programmer, constantly honing my problem-solving skills and algorithmic thinking.

My development environment is powered by Arch Linux, Neovim, and a minimal setup that maximizes productivity. While I specialize in backend development, I'm also comfortable working with frontend technologies when needed.

workflow.title: Workflow :-
workflow.description:
I use Arch for full control—lean, fast, and free of bloat. My workflow is built for speed and clarity: Neovim for precision, tmux for flow, Git for discipline.

I automate the repetitive, map tools to muscle memory, and keep my stack minimal so I can focus purely on solving problems—whether it's building APIs with Hono, wiring UI in React, or optimizing servers.

currentlyExploring.title: Currently Exploring :-
currentlyExploring.description:
I'm actively participating in competitive programming contests on platforms like CodeForces and LeetCode to strengthen my algorithmic problem-solving skills.

Simultaneously, I'm exploring advanced concepts in distributed systems, microservices architecture, and cloud-native development. Working on implementing scalable backend solutions using Node.js and TypeScript, with a focus on performance optimization and system design.

details.title: Details :-
details.description:
This snapshot captures my full coding environment in action — minimal, focused, and keyboard-driven. I'm using Neovim (NvChad-based) as my editor, enhanced with Telescope, LSPs, and Tree-sitter for seamless navigation and syntax clarity.

The workspace is managed by Hyprland, my dynamic tiling window manager, where every window flows smoothly between workspaces. The terminal running below is Kitty, and the shell is Fish — tuned for performance and efficiency with autosuggestions and rich prompts.

A lofi playlist or a TED talk usually plays in the background, keeping the vibes calm and focused. Each detail in this setup — from status bars to plugin load times — reflects my goal of building in an environment that’s both minimal and powerful.

hono.title: Why I Picked Hono Over Express for My APIs
hono.subtitle: I switched from Express to Hono for building APIs—and it changed everything. Here's why Hono's speed, simplicity, and TypeScript-first approach won me over.

sections.title: What is Hono?
sections.content: Hono is a lightweight, fast web framework tailored for modern edge platforms like Cloudflare Workers, Vercel, and Bun. It offers simple syntax and native TypeScript support.

sections.title: Why I Moved Away from Express
list: Heavier setup: Express felt too bloated for small APIs.
Middleware complexity: Managing and chaining middleware became messy.
TypeScript overhead: Getting types to work well took too much configuration.

sections.title: Why Hono Works Better for Me
list: Faster performance: Especially on edge runtimes.
Minimalistic syntax: Straightward and readable.
TypeScript-first design: Built-in types for routes and contexts.
Small bundle size: Great for microservices and serverless.

code.title: Express Example
Hono Example
code.snippet:
import { Hono } from 'hono'
const app = new Hono()
app.get('/', (c) => c.text('Hello from Hono!'))
export default app

sections.title: Conclusion
sections.content: Hono has proven to be a leaner, more developer-friendly choice for building APIs in modern JavaScript environments. If you're using TypeScript and care about performance, it's worth checking out.

sections.title: CLI Workflow
sections.content: My workflow is centered around the terminal. I use Fish as my shell, which provides features like autosuggestions, syntax highlighting, and a rich ecosystem of plugins. I use Tmux for session management, allowing me to have multiple persistent sessions and switch between them seamlessly.

sections.title: Editor
sections.content: I use Neovim as my primary text editor. I have a custom configuration based on NvChad that is tailored to my needs. I use a variety of plugins to enhance my productivity, including Telescope for fuzzy finding, LSP for code intelligence, and Tree-sitter for syntax highlighting.

sections.title: Window Management
sections.content: I use Hyprland as my window manager on Arch Linux. It is a dynamic tiling window manager that allows me to manage my windows efficiently. I have a custom configuration that is optimized for my workflow.

details.title: Neovim with Telescope
details.description: This is my Neovim setup with the Telescope plugin open. Telescope is a fuzzy finder that I use for everything from finding files to searching for text in my project.

details.title: Neovim with LSP
details.description: Here you can see my Neovim setup with the LSP (Language Server Protocol) in action. I get real-time diagnostics, code completion, and other language-specific features directly in my editor.

details.title: My Terminal Setup
details.description: This is my terminal setup. I use Kitty as my terminal emulator and Fish as my shell. The prompt is customized to show the current git branch and other useful information.

neovim.title: Swapped VSCode for Neovim — Powered by NvChad
neovim.subtitle: I ditched VSCode and entered the world of Neovim with NvChad. Here's how this fast, keyboard-first setup supercharged my workflow—and why I think every dev should give it a try.

sections.title: What is NvChad?
sections.content: NvChad is a Neovim configuration that provides a beautiful and fast experience out of the box. It comes with a set of sensible defaults and a curated list of plugins that make it easy to get started with Neovim.

sections.title: Why I Switched
list: Performance: Neovim is incredibly fast and lightweight.
Keyboard-driven: I can do everything from the keyboard, which is much more efficient.
Customization: I can customize every aspect of my editor to fit my workflow.
Community: The Neovim community is amazing and there are tons of great plugins available.

sections.title: My Favorite Plugins
list: Telescope: A fuzzy finder that I use for everything.
LSP: For code intelligence and diagnostics.
Tree-sitter: For syntax highlighting and code navigation.
Git signs: To see git changes directly in the editor.

sections.title: Conclusion
sections.content: Switching to Neovim has been a game-changer for my productivity. It took some time to get used to the modal editing and the keyboard-driven workflow, but it was well worth it. If you're a developer who values speed and efficiency, I highly recommend giving Neovim a try.

git-cli.title: Git CLI

sections.title: Project Overview
sections.content: A meticulous, hands-on project to implement the core features of the Git version control system from the ground up, following the CodeCrafters challenge. This repository serves as a deep dive into the internal mechanics of Git, covering everything from object storage and hashing to branch management.

Hash objects and store them in the object database
Create commit objects
Create and manage branches
